availability.p: All research and writing of Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition annotations was undertaken by project staff, volunteers, and interns. Each record contains citations to relevant primary and secondary source material. All annotations are copyright Kentucky Historical Society, and should be referenced as such in any published work.

seriesStmt.title: Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition

body.p: Also spelled Frazier, Fraser or Frazer. Titus was born in Tennessee in 1800. Titus moved to Memphis, Shelby County, Tennessee in 1822. There he worked as a Commission Merchant and Cotton Factor. In 1860, he owned 20 slaves. He was a secessionist and supported the Confederacy during the war. He served as the head of the Committee of Safety and Vigilance in Memphis, Shelby County, Tennessee during the war. Died on June 30, 1870.

bibl.p: Leon Trousdale, Wm. T. Avery, W. B. Waldran, J. P. Prescott eds., Old Folksâ€™ Historical Record (Memphis: R. C. Hite, 1875), 7, 15, 215; Find A Grave, "Col Frazer Titus (1800 - June 30, 1870)," Memorial #93725237, https://www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GSln=TI&GSpartial=1&GSbyrel=all&GSst=45&GScntry=4&GSsr=8361&GRid=93725237& (accessed June 27, 2017).; Seventh Manuscript Census of the United States (1850), Population Schedules, Tennessee, Shelby County, 1st Ward City of Memphis; Ninth Manuscript Census of the United States (1870), Population Schedules, Tennessee, Shelby County, First Ward Memphis, p. 118. James B. Jones Jr., Hidden History of Civil War Tennessee (Charleston, SC: The History Press, 2013), 9-10.
